title.narrative: OUTPUT 1.1. DEMAND FOR HEALTH, NUT & HIV SERVICES

description.narrative: By end 2021, parents, pregnant women, women of reproductive age, mothers and adolescents have the knowledge, financial resources and social empowerment to access quality health services, which contributes to Access To Quality Learning Opportunities, Child Health, Cross-Sectoral - Social And Behaviour Change, Cross-Sectoral Communication For Development, Health And Development In Early Childhood And Adolescence, Health â€“ General, Immunization, Immunization Services As Part Of Primary Health Care, Learning, Skills, Participation And Engagement, Maternal And Newborn Health, Mental Health And Psychosocial Well-Being, Nutrition Of Adolescents And Women, Polio Eradication, Strengthening Primary Health Care And High-Impact Health Interventions. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Advocacy And Communications, Advocacy And Public Engagement, Community Engagement, Social And Behaviour Change, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: Outcome 1. By the end of 2022, adolescents, pregnant and lactating women, mothers and children 0-5 years of age are using more quality health services in the 10 targeted provinces.

title.narrative: By end 2021, parents, pregnant women, women of reproductive age, mothers and adolescents have the knowledge, financial resourcesand social empowerment to access quality health services

description.narrative: Despite a continued, challenging COVID-19 context in 2021, health facilities and community-based interventions were strengthened, which allowed to maintain women and children’s access to information and basic health, nutrition, and HIV interventions. The independent monitoring of polio vaccination campaigns revealed that 95% of parents were informed on October campaign before the date of his launch in 136 districts and 96% for the November campaign in 93 districts (95% in November 2020). The organization of the World Prematurity month raised the need to have a strategic health plan for children, especially newborns which include normative documents of the Kangaroo Care method. | Status:Constrained | As-of Date:24/01/2022
